hints.content:
Lets figure out the factors for the rows and columns. Then we can multiply to find the missing values.

![The same table as above, with the unknown numbers marked with question marks.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d67c82195a061372dcf33dab323d81e1da35a0e)

$49 \stackrel{\greenD{+7}}{\longrightarrow} 56 \stackrel{\greenD{+7}}{\longrightarrow} 63 $

The factor for the first column is $\greenD{7}$.

![The same table as above, with the first column labeled 7.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0a1b90652b660cf7495a17796ce9b5a36941eb5a)

The factor for each column of a multiplication table is one more than the column the left of it.

![The same table as above, with the columns labeled 7, 8, and 9 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/36b8c572b6b9830bbbf638c4fd77336cfd76094a)

$56 \stackrel{\blueD{+8}}{\longrightarrow} 64 \stackrel{\blueD{+8}}{\longrightarrow} 72$

The factor for the second row is $\blueD{8}$.

![The same table as above, with the second row labeled 8.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d0814e3fc68ee6b967221b197fab5d9d04ba4fa)

The factor for each row of a multiplication table is one more than the row above it.

![The same table as above, with the rows labeled 7, 8 and 9 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/8c5bcbaa8cff9dca386c9c9eb024ded8a9aff629)

Now we know the factors, so we can multiply to find the missing numbers.

$7 \times 8 = 56$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 7 and column 8 labeled 56.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/953ddcda7d55e3bea548f4293a0e039856e0f9b7)

$9 \times 9 = 81$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 9 and column 9 labeled 81.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/2013601ce95f639d6a465b7739c6bba620da094d)

Here is the completed pattern.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 49, 56, 63. The second row reads 56, 64, 72. The third row reads 63, 72, 81. !

question.content:
Part of a multiplication table is below.

**Complete the pattern in the multiplication table.**

[[☃ label-image 1]]

options.imageAlt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 49, an unknown number, 63. The second row reads 56, 64, 72. The third row 63, 72, an unknown number.

markers.label: The unknown number in the first row and second column
The unknown number in the third row and third column
